question: Who was this fuckin' guy?
answer: Rock and roll, Gus. Johnny Boz.

question: I never heard of him.
answer: Before your time, pop. Mid-sixties. Five or six hits. He's got a club down in the Fillmore now.

question: Not now he don't.
answer: You guys know Captain Talcott?

question: What's the Chief's office doin' here.
answer: What do you think, Doc? Nobody say anything. The maid came in an hour ago and found him. She's not a live-in.

question: Maybe the maid did it.
answer: She's 54 years old and weighs 240 pounds.

question: It ain't the maid.
answer: He left the club with his girlfriend about midnight. That's the last time anybody saw him.

question: I'm Detective Curran, this is Detective Moran. We're with the San Francisco Police Department.
answer: Ain't that cute? They got his and her Pig-assos, son.

question: I didn't know you knew who Picasso was, Gus.
answer: I'm a smart sonofabitch. I just hide it.

question: Are you vice?
answer: Homicide.

question: What do you want?
answer: When was the last time you saw John Boz?

question: No. I'm an amateur.
answer: How long were you having sex with him?

question: About a year and a half.
answer: Were you with him last night?

question: Yes.
answer: Did you leave the club with him?

question: Yes.
answer: Did you go home with him?

question: No. We had a drink at the club. We left together. I came here. He went home.
answer: Was there anyone with you last night?

question: No. I wasn't in the mood to have sex with anyone last night.
answer: Let me ask you something, Ms. Tramell? Are you sorry he's dead?

question: I'm sorry, Beth. I -- I got hung up in Stinson.
answer: How are you, Nick?

question: I'm fine. Come on, Beth! You know I'm fine! How the hell long do I have to keep doing this?
answer: As long as Internal Affairs wants you to, I suppose. Sit down, Nick.

question: It's bullshit. You know it is.
answer: I know it is -- but sit down anyway so we can get it over with, okay? So -- how are things?

question: Things are fine. I told you. They're fine.
answer: How is your -- personal life?

question: My sex life is fine. My sex life is pretty shitty actually since I stopped seeing you -- maybe I should think about my Electrolux again. Sorry.
answer: How about the booze?

question: It's been three months.
answer: How about the coke?

question: No.
answer: No?

question: No! I'm working my tail off. I'm off the sauce, I'm not even smoking anymore.
answer: How's not smoking?

question: It's fucked -- now will you please tell I.A. that I'm just you average healthy totally fucked-up cop and let me get out of here?
answer: Yes.

question: Thank you.
answer: I still miss you, Nick.

question: Bobby Vasquez, former middleweight contender, killed in the ring Atlantic City, 1984.
answer: I love it. She's got a hundred million bucks. She fucks fighters and rock and roll stars. And she's got a degree in screwing with peoples' heads.

question: You forgot her degree in literature. She's a writer. She published a novel last year under a pen name. Do you want to know what it's about? It's about a retired rock and roll star who is murdered by his girlfriend.
answer: Page 67, pop. Do you know how she does the boyfriend? With an icepick, in bed, his hands tied with a white silk scarf.

question: Ms. Tramell, we'd like you to come downtown and answer some questions for us.
answer: Are you arresting me?

question: If that's the way you want to play it.
answer: Can I change into something more appropriate? It'll just take a minute. Come in. How long will this take?

question: I don't know. Do you always keep old newspapers around?
answer: Only when they make interesting reading. I'm ready.

question: Why would I need an attorney? Do you have a cigarette?
answer: I don't smoke.

question: Yes, you do.
answer: I quit. I thought you were out of cigarettes.

question: I found some in my purse; would you like one?
answer: I told you -- I quit.

question: It won't last.
answer: You workin' on another book?

question: Yes I am.
answer: It must really be somehtin' --makin' stuff up all the time.

question: It teaches you to lie.
answer: How's that?

question: You make it up, but it has to be believable. They call it suspension of disbelief.
answer: I like that. "Suspension of Disbelief."

question: I have nothing to hide.
answer: There is no smoking in this building, Ms. Tramell.

question: What are you going to do? Charge me with smoking?
answer: Would you tell us the nature of your relationship with Mr. Boz?

question: I had sex with him for about a year and a half. I liked having sex with him. He wasn't afraid of experimenting. I like men like that. I like men who give me pleasure. He gave me a lot of pleasure.
answer: Did you ever engage in sado- masochistic activity with him?

question: Exactly what do you have in mind, Mr. Corrigan.
answer: Did you ever tie him up?

question: Yes it was. Bobby died.
answer: How did you feel when he died?

question: I loved him. I hurt.
answer: How did you feel when I told you Johnny Boz had died -- that day at the beach.

question: I felt somebody had read my book and was playing a game.
answer: But you didn't hurt --

question: No.
answer: Because you didn't love him --

question: That's right.
answer: Even though you were fucking him.

question: Can I ask one of you for a ride?
answer: Sure.

question: Thanks. I'm tired.
answer: It's got to be tiring to beat that machine.

question: If I were guilty, and if I wanted to beat that machine, it wouldn't be tiring. It wouldn't be tiring at all.
answer: Why not?

question: Because I'm a professional liar. I spend most of my waking hours dwelling on my lies. For my writing. I love the rain, don't you? You took a polygraph after you shot those two people, didn't you?
answer: I passed.

question: You see? We're both innocent, Nick.
answer: How do you know all this stuff about me?

question: You know all about me.
answer: I don't know anything that isn't police business.

question: It's my first drink in three months. That okay with you, pop? She doesn't know me. I never saw her before Gus and I talked to her. Thanks, Harry.
answer: You sure?

question: I'm sure. Now what?
answer: What now what? Now nothing. She passed the polygraph. That's it.

question: She knew she could beat it. That's why she asked to take it.
answer: How the fuck do you know? What is it with you and this broad anyway?

question: Come on, Phil. You're not gonna let this slide. What about her parents? What about what else she's published? At least we should get the stuff to see if we find anything else that's an amazing real-life coincidence.
answer: Her parents died in an accident. I don't care what else she's written. What are you -- a book critic?

question: How did they die? Was there an investigation?
answer: How you're saying she killed her parents? Did she kill Bobby Vasquez, too?

question: You okay?
answer: Yeah.

question: You don't look so okay.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: Baby-sitting. Rookie cop.
answer: What else is new? You want to get out of here?

question: Don't -- please, Nick -- Please don't -- don't -- What was she like?
answer: Who?

question: Catherine Tramell.
answer: She said what you said she'd say.

question: I met her at Berkeley. We were in some of the same classes.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: I'm telling you. You've never been... like that... before. Why?
answer: You're the shrink.

question: You weren't making love to me.
answer: Who was I making love to?

question: You weren't making love.
answer: I need a cigarette.

question: Shit.
answer: Ain't you go nothin' better to do than to come in here and jack off the damn machine?

question: What are you doing here, Pop?
answer: I came in here to jack off the damn machine. One dead psychology professor. Noah Goldstein. Dr. Noah Goldstein. And guess what? He was her counselor.

question: Was she ever suspect?
answer: No, sir. They never even got a statement from her.

question: Do you remember a case -- 1956 -- Hazel Dobkins?
answer: Hell yes! Couldn't get it outta my head for years. Still can't. Nice little kids -- nice husband, wasn't porkin' around -- no financial problems. One day -- outta the clear blue sky -- she does 'em. All of 'em. Used a knife. He got for a wedding present. Didn't even deny it. Sweet as honey. Said she didn't know why she done it.

question: Hi.
answer: Am I... disturbing you?

question: No. Come in. I'm using you for my detective. In my book. You don't mind, do you? Would you like a drink? I was just going to have one.
answer: No, thanks.

question: That's right. You're off the Jack Daniels too, aren't you?
answer: I'd like to ask you a few more questions.

question: I'd like to ask you some, too. For my book.
answer: What kind of questions?

question: How does it feel to kill someone?
answer: You tell me.

question: I don't know. But you do.
answer: It was an accident. They got in the line of fire.

question: Four shootings in five years. All accidents.
answer: They were drug buys. I was a vice cop. Tell me about Professor Goldstein.

question: There's a name from the past.
answer: You want a name from the present? How about Hazel Dobkins?

question: Noah was my counselor in my freshman year. That's probably where I got the idea for the icepick. For my book. Funny how the subconscious works. Hazel is my friend.
answer: She wiped out her whole family.

question: Yes. She's helped me understand homicidal impulse.
answer: Didn't you study it in school?

question: Only in theory. You know all about homicidal impulse, don't you, shooter? Not in theory -- in practice. What happened, Nick? Did you get sucked into it? Did you like it too much?
answer: No.

question: Tell me about the coke, Nick. The day you shot those two tourists -- how much coke did you do? Tell me, Nick.
answer: I didn't.

question: Yes, you did. They never tested you, did they? But Internal Affairs knew. Your wife knew, didn't she? She knew what was going on. Nicky got too close to the flame. Nicky liked it. That's why she killed herself? Hiya, hon. You two have met, haven't you? You're going to make a terrific character, Nick.
answer: Who has access to my file?

question: Who has access to my file?
answer: What are you talking about, Nick -- what's wrong with you?

question: Who's got access to my goddamn file?
answer: Nobody. It's a confidential psychiatric record, it'd be illegal --She backs into a wall. She looks very scared. He comes very close to her -- puts an arm behind her to the wall.

question: Don't, Beth. Don't lie to me. It's Internal Affairs, isn't it?
answer: No, Nick, please --

question: Who?
answer: Nilsen.

question: What do you want, Curran?
answer: You sold her the file, didn't you?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: What'd she pay you?

question: What's goin' down, son?
answer: Nothin' I'll be okay, pop.

question: No, sir. You won't. There's smoke off yonder on the horizon. They're gonna want your badge.
answer: I got tired of being played with.

question: You sure got real conclusive ways of demonstrating that.
answer: She knows where I live and breathe. She's coming after me.

question: What is it you got between you?
answer: I don't know.

question: Somethin', though.
answer: Yeah. Somethin'.

question: Yeah. Somethin'.
answer: I still have my key.

question: I don't want to see you, Beth.
answer: Damnit! Don't shut me out! You owe me more than that?

question: I don't owe you anything; you don't owe me anything. We went to bed -- what was it? -- ten or fifteen times? It wasn't memorable enough to carry any obligations.
answer: Sometimes I really hate you.

question: Yeah? Well why don't you find some friendly therapist and work some of that hostility out. But take my advice. Put a little more life into it than you usually do.
answer: I'm sorry... I don't usually... act like that.

question: How could you let him have my file, Beth?
answer: He was going to recommend your discharge a behavioral disability. I made a deal with him. He could review the session notes himself. It was the only way I could keep you on the force.

question: You did it for me.
answer: Yes. I care about you. I did it for you.

question: Where were you tonight?
answer: Home. Watching TV.

question: All night?
answer: Yeah.

question: Were you drinking?
answer: Yeah, I was drinking.

question: When did you start drinking again?
answer: A couple days ago.

question: I'll get my stuff tomorrow. Beth. Thank you.
answer: It's the least I could do... considering I got you into this mess with those reports.

question: No. I mean it, thank you.
answer: How do you know Catherine Tramell saw my reports?

question: She knows stuff about me that only you know.
answer: She must really be something. From a clinical point of view.

question: What was she like in school?
answer: I hardly knew her. She gave me the creeps, though. I don't know why. Get some rest. Promise?

question: Beth. I didn't mean what I said. About --
answer: Yes you did. I'm a big girl. I can handle it.

question: Take care, you hear?
answer: Did you find out about her parents?

question: You're on leave, man. You're on psycho leave. I'm talking to a possible whacko here.
answer: You know I'm whacko, Sam, what'd you find?

question: The boat blew. There was a leak in the gas line. There were two previous repairs. There was a five-mil policy on both of 'em. A real heavy investigation. Zilch. Goose-egg. It was an accident.
answer: Thanks.

question: Thanks.
answer: I.A.'s going to talk to you more about Nilsen. They're handling the investigation, we're not. Stay in touch with Dr. Gardner, it'll help on the evaluation.

question: She killed him.
answer: Beth? Now you've got Beth killing people?

question: Catherine Tramell. It's part of her game.
answer: First you've got her buying your file. Now you've got her killing Nilsen. Forget her, willya? Go someplace. Sit in the sun. Get away from this goddamn fog. Get her out of your system.

question: You don't but it, do you? She knew nobody would but it. She knew I'd say she did it. And she knew nobody would buy it.
answer: She's screwing with your head, Nick. Pretty soon you're gonna look in the mirror and think you're seeing her.

question: I heard about what happened. What good's a shooter without his gun?
answer: How exactly did you hear?

question: I have attorneys. They have friends. I have friends. Money buys you a lot of attorneys and friends.
answer: I don't know about that I don't have any money I don't have any attorneys Gus is my only real friend.

question: I wasn't talking about real friends. Why doesn't Gus like me.
answer: I like you.

question: Do you?
answer: Yeah. Would you like to come up and have a drink?

question: I didn't think you'd ask me.
answer: I'm not that easy to figure.

question: You're not easy to figure. I'm just very good at figuring.
answer: Don't get too cocky.

question: Why not?
answer: You can make a mistake.

question: Not me. You should put some warmth into it. You don't want it to reflect on your personality.
answer: Jack Daniel's okay? It's gonna have to be.

question: Fine.
answer: Ice?

question: Please. Let me do that. You like to watch me doing it, don't you? Can I have a cigarette, please? I told you you'd start smoking again. Light it for me, will you? Thank you.
answer: What did you pay Nilsen?

question: Isn't he the policeman that you shot, Shooter?
answer: What if I asked you not to call me Shooter?

question: What if I call you Nicky?
answer: My wife used to call me that.

question: I know, Nicky, but I like it. Cheers. My friends call me Catherine.
answer: What did Bobby Vasquez used to call you?

question: Bitch mostly, but he meant it affectionately. You don't have any coke, do you? I love coke and Jack Daniel's.
answer: There's Pepsi in the fridge.

question: It's not the same thing, is it?
answer: Where's it going? What do you want from me?

question: Say -- "What do you want from me, Catherine?"
answer: What do you want from me, Catherine?

question: I brought you something. Aren't you going to thank me?
answer: What's it about?

question: A boy kills his parents. They have a plane. He makes it look like an accident.
answer: Why does he do it?

question: To see if he can get away with it.
answer: When did you write it?

question: You mean did I write it before my parents died?
answer: Yes.

question: No. I wrote it years afterwards. You're not going to stop following me around now just because you're on leave -- are you?
answer: No.

question: Good. I'd miss you. You can get into trouble, though. You're not really a cop anymore.
answer: I'll risk it.

question: Why take the risk?
answer: To see if I can get away with it. How's your new book?

question: I'm getting deeper and deeper into my character. Thanks for the drink. I'm leaving the house around midnight. In case you're going to follow me. I'm going down to Johnny's club.
answer: I'll meet you there.

question: I know what that's like. Tell me something, Rocki. Man-to- man. I think she's the fuck of the century, don't you? How long you been here, Rock? You like to watch, do you?
answer: Nicky.

question: 'Morning. I think Roxy got jealous.
answer: She's seen me fuck plenty of other guys.

question: Maybe she saw something she didn't see before.
answer: She's seen everything before.

question: She's never seen us before.
answer: Did you think it was so special?

question: I told her it was the fuck of the century. What did you think?
answer: I thought it was a pretty good beginning.

question: How about Roxy? Is she a fuck to the century, too?
answer: Do you want her to join us sometime?

question: I didn't mean for me -- I meant for you.
answer: I'm not as judgmental about women as I am about men.

question: How's your shoulder?
answer: Fine. How's your back?

question: It hurts.
answer: We're alike, you know.

question: Are you kidding? You think this is my idea of morning-after conversation?
answer: Do you want personal insights and adolescent secrets? I don't do those.

question: You mean getting inside you isn't going to get me any deeper into your character.
answer: Not unless you confuse my character with my body parts. Were you frightened, Nicky?

question: I thought that business with the scarf was pretty nifty.
answer: I told you I had a vivid imagination. You shouldn't play this game.

question: I don't have a choice.
answer: You're in over your head.

question: I know.
answer: I've got a book to write. I'll see you around, Shooter.

question: What is this place? Hillbilly heaven?
answer: Where in the fuck you been? I went over to your place.

question: Easy there, partner -- I wasn't there.
answer: I went over last night, too.

question: I wasn't there last night, either.
answer: You... fucked her! Goddamn dumb sonofabitch... You fucked her! Goddamn, you are one dumb sonofabitch --

question: I'm not gonna get AIDS, pop --don't worry about it. I always use a rubber.
answer: I don't give a... flyin'... chili- bean... fart about AIDS!

question: You oughta use a rubber, pop. You really should.
answer: What in the hell for? You think I'm gettin' any at my age? I don't like blue-haired women. I don't like 'em.

question: You don't like punk rockers?
answer: Say what?

question: You feeling better?
answer: I feel fine! How could you fuck her? You wanna die, son? What is it -- those goddamn tourists -- you still feel so bad about that you're wigglin' your way into an icepi -- We got too many goddamn tourists comin' here anyway -- plenty more goddamn tourists where they goddamn came from.

question: I'm not afraid of her.
answer: Why the hell not?

question: I don't know. I'm just not.
answer: That's her pussy talkin' --He gets a real nasty look from a very fat woman eating a cheeseburger. He winks at her. The woman looks away from him, shaking her head. It ain't your brain. I.A. done did a track on Lt. Martin D for Dickhead Nilsen. They found a safety deposit box with fifty- thousand dollars in it, taken out three months ago, used that one time.

question: It doesn't make sense. She didn't know me three months ago.
answer: Maybe it wasn't her that paid him. Maybe the money was for somethin' else. How the fuck do I know? I'm just an old city cowboy tryin' not to fall outta his saddle.

question: You all right, pop? You want me to drive you?
answer: In that little pissant car of yours? Hell, no. I ain't gettin' no back pain disability retirement -- I'm gettin' me a full pension and a real gold-plate Seiko watch.

question: Come on, I'll drive you in this thing.
answer: You think I'd let you drive my Cadillac car? I ain't lettin' no hear-up-his-ass person drive my Cadillac car.

question: The Porsche dodges around cars very fast, almost side-swiping them, looking almost out of control, its MOTOR screaming.
answer: He sees the Ferrari turn ahead. When he gets to where it turned, he turns wildly.

question: The Ferrari is making fast, wild turns into little streets in North Beach, its MOTOR screaming -- the Porsche is gaining ground behind it, making turns.
answer: The Ferrari is up ahead and makes a wild right turn onto a road going up a hillside. He yanks the wheel hard. As it crests the steps and gets to the street. Nick GUNS it and it looks like it flies high down the hill-side into blackness.

question: But it lands on more steps -- heading downward -- bucking, almost spinning, it bounces onto the next street.
answer: Another set of steps leading up he GUNS it, it rockets up, ROARS, bucking --

question: And lands on the next street. Nick makes a wild right turn onto the street. And the black Ferrari appears from around a curve to the right, heading right for him.
answer: Nick steps on the GAS and heads head-on for the Ferrari.

question: Tell me again. I want to hear you say it again.
answer: It was an accident.

question: You're driving around North Beach for no particular reason and this car won't get out of the way --
answer: I don't think she meant to go off the hill, do you?

question: Who are you guys gonna sell my file to this time?
answer: Hello, Nick. This is Dr. Myron and R. McElwaine. They've been asked to consult with me on this evaluation.

question: Number one I don't remember how often I used to jack off, but it was a lot. Number two I didn't get pissed off at my dad -- even after I was old enough to know what he and mom were doing in the bedroom. Number three I don't look in the toilet before I flush it. Number four I don't wet the bed and haven't for some time. Number five You can go fuck yourselves because I'm out of here.
answer: What is your problem? I'm trying to help you. Why won't you let me help you?

question: I don't need any help.
answer: Yes you do. Something's on with you. You're sleeping with her, aren't you?

question: What is this interest you've got in her?
answer: My interest is in you, not in her. She seduces people, she manipulates --

question: I thought you hardly know her.
answer: I know the type. I'm a psychologist.

question: That means you manipulate people too, doesn't it, Beth? You're a practicing psychologist -- that means you're better at it than she is.
answer: I feel sorry for you, Nick.

question: Catherine! Catherine!
answer: I should have known. I came into the house when you were down on the beach. She looked at me so strangely. She left right after you. I shouldn't have let her watch us. She wanted to watch me all the time. She tried to kill you, didn't she?

question: Did you like her to watch?
answer: Do you think I told her to kill You?

question: No.
answer: Everybody that I care about dies.

question: It's OK. It's OK.
answer: Make love to me.

question: Do you think she killed Johnny Boz?
answer: For what... to set me up? She loved me she wouldn't frame me.

question: Maybe she got jealous of Johnny Boz, too.
answer: No, she didn't... she never got jealous before... she got excited. I don't have luck with women. There was this girl I met while I was in college. I slept with her once. She started following me around, taking my picture. She dyed her hair, copied my clothes. Lisa something... Oberman. It was awful.

question: I thought you didn't do adolescent secrets.
answer: I never have before. Isn't it just beautiful? I love it here like this.

question: We're still playing games, aren't we?
answer: No.

question: No?
answer: No more games, Nick. I'm tired of playing games!

question: Then tell me about Nilsen.
answer: You won't believe me.

question: Try me.
answer: I paid him $50,000 in cash for your psychiatric file.

question: When?
answer: About three months before I met you.

question: Why?
answer: I'd read about your shootings in the papers. I decided to write a book about a detective. I wanted to know my character.

question: You paid $50,000 for your character?
answer: I would've paid more. I wanted to know everything about you. Then you came down here after Johnny got killed... it gave me a chance to get to know my character better.

question: What about the other night. What about last night? Was that to get to know your character?
answer: Maybe I'm losing interest in my book. Do you believe me?

question: I don't know.
answer: I'll convince you. Hello? It's Gus-who-doesn't-like-me.

question: You know that stuff they say about how you can judge people by their friends?
answer: I don't believe it.

question: Why not?
answer: You're my friend, Gus.

question: I'm gonna make you believe in it, friend.
answer: How old was she when this happened?

question: Anderson. Jack W. Donald M. I'm sorry. No Lisa.
answer: Did you check all four years?

question: Yes I did.
answer: Can you check again?

question: No Lisa Anderson, detective.
answer: Can there be some mistake?

question: Hazel , this is Nick. I told you all about him. This is Hazel Dobkins.
answer: Fine. Thank you. Can I talk to you a minute?

question: Honey, why don't you go in the car? I'll be right there.
answer: You like to hang out with murderers or what? Did you know Roxy --

question: Of course I knew. Look. Sometimes when I do my research, I get involved with people. It happened with you, too. Killing isn't like smoking. You can quit. I've go to go. I promised to get her home by six o'clock. She just loves "America's Most Wanted."
answer: There was no Lisa Anderson at Berkeley when you were there.

question: What were you doing, checking up on me? What for? Henderson.
answer: Henderson. Lisa Henderson. With an H. You do?

question: Henderson. Lisa Henderson. With an H. You do?
answer: I can get my butt kicked for this. You're not supposed to be in here.

question: It's not gonna take long, Sam. Bring it up, will you, Sam?
answer: Hey, that's Dr. Gardner, isn't it?

question: Bring 1976 up. You shouldn't leave your door open.
answer: I didn't. Something's wrong with my lock. What do you want, Nick?

question: Tell me about Catherine.
answer: She told you, didn't she?

question: What did she tell me, Beth?
answer: I slept with her once in school. I was just a kid. I was experimenting. It was just that one time. She developed a... fixation... on me. She styled her hair like mine. She wore the same kind of clothes I did. It scared me. Isn't that what she told you?

question: She told me it was you. You wore the same kind of clothes. You dyed your hair blonde.
answer: I did dye my hair. It didn't have anything to do with her. I was a redhead for a while, too.

question: Did you know Noah Goldstein?
answer: I had him in two classes.

question: You saw all the reports, Beth!
answer: What do I say -- Hey, listen, guys, I'm not gay, but I did fuck your suspect. I was embarrassed. It's the only time I've been with a woman. She's really sick you know. Don't you know what she's doing? She knows I went to Berkeley. She knows I knew Noah. She makes up that story about me. She's handing you somebody who's obsessed with he her.

question: She didn't hand you to me. She doesn't even know who you are. She told me about Lisa Henderson.
answer: She knew you'd find out who Lisa Henderson is. You're a good cop -- what did she do? Tell you casually and make it seem irrelevant? Did she tell you in bed, Nick? That's how I'd do it.

question: Why did you change your name?
answer: I got married. He was on staff at the clinic. I was down in Salinas. It didn't... last long. Nick -- Do you really think I... that I could kill someone... I never even met Johnny Boz. What about Nilsen? What possible motive would I have to kill him?

question: You should do something about this lock.
answer: She's evil. She's brilliant. Be careful, Nick.

question: Do I scare you, Nick? I just thought I'd surprise you. What's the matter?
answer: I found Lisa Henderson.

question: Did you? What's she doing? You're not going to tell me what she's doing. I thought we weren't playing games anymore.
answer: I did, too. She told me it was backwards -- she said you even styled your hair the way she did.

question: And you believed her? I even went down to the campus police and made out a report about her. You still think I kill people, don't you?
answer: No.

question: Liar.
answer: Homicide. San Francisco. What do you mean it's not here?

question: Homicide. San Francisco. What do you mean it's not here?
answer: So Nilsen had a report on her -- so what. You don't know what the hell was in it?

question: Catherine told me what was in it.
answer: If she's telling you the truth.

question: Don't you get it, Gus? If Beth killed Johnny Boz to frame Catherine -- she wouldn't want anyone to know what happened at Berkeley. It gives her the motive to kill Nilsen.
answer: How did she know Nilsen knew about it -- if it happened?

question: He was I.A. He probably asked her about it.
answer: She'd have to be nuttier than a twenty-pound Christmas fruitcake. She's not the one who hangs out with multiple murderers -- your girlfriend is.

question: She's a writer -- it's part of what she does.
answer: Goddamn writers -- all they do is use up trees and ruin people's eyes. There's gotta be somebody at Berkeley who knows what the hell happened.

question: I know what happened. Catherine told me what happened.
answer: You got goddamn tweety-birds flutterin' around your head, that's what you got. You think you're gonna fuck like minks, raise rugrats, and live happily ever after? Oh, man.

question: How'd you get in here?
answer: I decided to give you one more chance. I missed you.

question: You didn't not see me long enough to miss me.
answer: Did you miss me?

question: No.
answer: Come over here and tell me no.

question: No. That's below the belt.
answer: Not yet it isn't. But we're getting there.

question: I have to do some research tomorrow.
answer: I'm very good at research. I'll help you.

question: No thanks.
answer: What are you researching?

question: I'm writing a book.
answer: Really. What are you writing about.

question: A detective. He falls for the wrong girl.
answer: What happens to them?

question: They fuck like minks, raise rugrats, and live happily ever after.
answer: It won't sell.

question: Why not?
answer: Somebody has to die.

question: Why?
answer: Somebody always does.

question: He was shot.
answer: He was walking home from work. They only lived a coupla blocks from the clinic. Somebody drove by and shot him.

question: What was the weapon?
answer: .38 revolver. Never recovered.

question: Were there ever any suspects?
answer: No suspects, no motive. Unsolved.

question: Was his wife ever a suspect?
answer: I had another one of you guys down here from Frisco -- about a year ago -- he asked me the same question. What's this about anyway?

question: Routine.
answer: Yeah, he said it was routine too. Now it's two guys saying it's routine.

question: Do you remember his name?
answer: Nope, can't say that I do.

question: Nilsen?
answer: That's him.

question: Was she ever a suspect?
answer: Nope. There was some talk; it never panned.

question: What kind of talk?
answer: The usual -- a girlfriend.

question: He had a girlfriend?
answer: Nope. She did. Like I say. It never panned.

question: Thanks.
answer: I hope I helped you out.

question: You did. Hi. I missed you. I finished my research.
answer: I finished my book.

question: How did it end?
answer: I told you. She kills him. Goodbye, Nick. I finished my book. Didn't you hear me?* Your character's dead. Goodbye. What do you want, Nick? Flowers? I'll send you some flowers.

question: What is this -- some kind of... Joke? Are we playing games again?
answer: The games are over. You were right. It was the fuck of the century, Shooter. Right there.

question: Gus!
answer: What are you doing here?

question: Put your hands up! Put your fucking hands up! Don't move.
answer: I got a message on my machine to meet Gus here. Where is he?

question: Don't! I know about your husband. You still like girls, Beth?
answer: What?

question: Take your hands out of your pockets!
answer: What is wrong with you? I loved you.

question: What made you think she had a gun? What the hell was she doing here? What was Gus doing here?
answer: Lieutenant.

question: Jesus.
answer: Thirty-eight caliber revolver.
